GNOME &version; Release Notes
Introduction
The GNOME &version; Desktop and Platform release is the latest version of the popular, multi-platform and free desktop environment.
GNOME is supported on a variety of platforms, including GNU/Linux (more commonly referred to as Linux), Solaris (tm) Operating Environment, HP-UX, BSD and Apple's Darwin. The user interface boasts powerful features such as high-quality smooth text rendering and first class internationalization and accessibility support, including support for bi-directional text.
GNOME &version; builds on the excellent GNOME 2.0.x releases, featuring enhanced font rendering using font-config and Xft technology, improved usability and theme support and a host of new utilities and applications. GNOME &version; also brings the first appearance of a new multimedia framework, called GStreamer, into the desktop.
GNOME is part of the GNU Project, and is free software.
What's New In GNOME &version;
Building on the excellent groundwork in the GNOME 2.0.x releases, we spent 6 months improving usability, performance and accessibility support. We also added new functionality, including new applications, producing a very feature-rich GNOME 2.2 desktop. You can read about these new features in the next few sections.
GNOME is now even more user-friendly yet complete for both everyday users and experienced developers. We have tried to avoid unnecessary complications or obscure features and hope that GNOME 2.2 demonstrates a clear, unified vision.
The GNOME 2 developer platform has matured further and is now widely used. While GNOME 2.0 was a major upgrade to the underlying platform which was inevitably delayed, GNOME &version; is a simpler time-based release which includes whatever improvements have been completed since the previous release. In future you can look forward to further enhancements from these regularly-scheduled releases.
Most major GNOME-based applications have been ported to GNOME 2, and the new platform has allowed the development of several new applications. We would encourage new and existing developers to use the GNOME 2.2 platform, to take advantage of its features.
Of course GNOME 2.2 includes all of the improvements made in GNOME 2.0, which you can learn about here.

Garnome
If you do not wish to go through the proccess of manually building each module yourself, then you might consider using GARNOME, a GNOME distribution based on the GAR ports system. GARNOME automatically downloads the tarballs from a specified location and builds them for you. To find out more information visit the GARNOME web page.

Known Issues
All software, when it is released, contains bugs the developers know about but have elected, for a variety of reasons, not to fix before releasing. Free software is no different in this regard from proprietary software, except that with free software, we tell users about them.
We also encourage our users to report bugs so that they can be fixed. The best way to report bugs found in GNOME is to use the Simple Bug Guide. This will take you through the necessary steps to file a quality bug report, and make sure that it is tagged appropriately. If you're too advanced for anything with the word 'simple' in it, there is also the traditional bug form.

Getting Involved
The core of GNOME's success is its many volunteers, both users and developers.
As a user, your contribution can be as simple as filing good bug reports against the GNOME Desktop and Developer Platform. You can file bugs in our Bugzilla using the simple bug assistant. If you feel that you would like to contribute more, then perhaps think about joining our active bug-squad.
From a developer aspect, there is much exciting progress to be made in any of our active developer groups - Accessibility, Documentation, Usability, Translation, Web, Testing, Graphics and Destkop & Platform Development. Many of these sub-projects have web pages on developer.gnome.org. Choosing a role that suits you may be difficult at first, but here is a guide to help you make your decision [TODO: link to joining-gnome].
Helping on GNOME can be an incredibly satisfying experience, allowing you to meet a wide range of motivated, skilled, and helpful people all working towards a unified goal. Join us today and see what a difference you can make.
